@0DanSmith @tomfed Phew! Though I did notice a Freudian slip of sorts when Reggie said "And man, what games?" What games indeed.
@tomfed @0DanSmith Yup, March always seemed like a tight turnaround. What's the pressure to release early (other than imminent Wii U death)?
@0DanSmith @tomfed Yep, bizarre. At least they had Luigi's Mansion for GCN launch... and how hard is it to make a Mario Kart game, really?
@tomfed @0DanSmith Literally the only one I saw was 1, 2 Switch. Mario as a holiday release is especially disappointing.
The key thing that struck me about the #NintendoSwitchPresentation is how few games seem deep in development. Not a great look.

@LadyCJD Not that long in history of constitutional amendments I guess. 27th Amendment proposed in 1789, adopted in... wait for it... 1992.
@LadyCJD It's all theoretical anyway because two-third majority in the House seems impossible, let alone ratification by 3/4 of states.
@LadyCJD Congress could theoretically flip in 2018 given incumbent disadvantage, but Dems defending more seats/Reps have a GOTV edge.
And of course the only way to get rid of it is a constitutional amendment - surely impossible in a country this divided. #ElectionNight

@arisharp even if less so than years gone by. Say what you will about revolving leadership, I think we get better representation. (2/2)
@arisharp Even though this US cycle is an anomaly I still take great comfort that our elections are much more policy-focussed, (1/2)
@arisharp And even though our elections sometimes feel presidential, the Westminster system still feels like it wins out.
@arisharp It's a good question. Our partisanship is so much less pronounced too - far fewer party registrations, much higher 3rd party vote
@arisharp I suspect Australian politicians might do the same if they had that kind of public personal support... but none of them do.
